children.name: story
children.definition: an untrue story or explanation that you use as an excuse or to impress sb:
examples: Where were you? And don’t give me some story about working late!
Well, that’s my story(= that is what I say happened ), and I’m sticking to it.

children.name: give sb some story
examples: She gave me some story about Mark being an old friend.

children.name: tall story
examples: It’s the sort of tall tale about how good they are with women that guys tell in bars.

children.name: cock-and-bull storyespecially British
examples: He gave me a cock-and-bull story about the glass being smashed in the storm, but it looked to me like the two of them had had a fight.

children.name: fiction
children.definition: an untrue story or piece of information that someone has deliberately invented: điều bịa đặt
examples: It can sometimes be difficult to tell fact from fiction.
pure fictioncompletely untrue and invented
The president denied that he was ill, labelling the report ‘pure fiction.’

children.name: fabrication
children.definition: an untrue story or piece of information that someone has deliberately invented in order to deceive people: bịa đặt
examples: ▪ Everything that was written about me in that article was a fabrication.

children.name: total/pure/complete fabrication
examples: ▪ The defense said that the victim’s story was a total fabrication designed to get revenge.

children.name: say or write sth that is not true
tell a lie
children.definition: to deliberately tell sb sth that is not true:
examples: The guy’s always telling lies.
Are you accusing me of telling lies?
The boys tell lies to get each other into trouble.

children.name: tell sb a lie
examples: Of course it’s true. I wouldn’t tell you a lie.

children.name: lie
children.definition: to deliberately tell sb sth that is not true: nói dối, xạo
examples: I looked at her face and just knew that she was lying.
lie to
Don’t lie to me! I know where you were last night.
lie about
Movie stars always lie about their age.
lie through your teeth[to deliberately say sth that is completely untrue, in a way that makes other people angry or upset] nói dối trơ trẽn
‘The witness was lying through his teeth,’ said Davis, ‘and should be charged with perjury.’

children.name: tell tales
children.definition: if sb, especially a child, tells tales, they tell lies about sb else, in order to make you believe that the other person has behaved badly: mách lẻo
examples: Daisy Venables, you naughty girl, have you been telling tales again?

children.name: tell tales on
examples: According to the children, telling tales on each other was as bad as cheating.

children.name: tell fibs
children.definition: /tell porkies   to tell lies, especially ones that are not very important - used especially by children:
examples: Now, Martin, you mustn’t tell fibs.
His mother says that he sometimes tells fibs.

children.name: fib
children.definition: to tell a lie - especially one that is not very important:
examples: When she asked if they wanted to stay for tea, Larry fibbed and said they had a few errands to run.

children.name: fib about
examples: He fibbed about his age.

children.name: be economical with the truth
children.definition: especially UK to not tell the whole truth about sth - use this in a humorous way to say indirectly that sb is lying: “tiết kiệm sự thât”
examples: Don’t you feel like you’re being a bit economical with the truth here?
Leonard had, as he put it, been ‘economical with the truth’ at times.

children.name: to invent a false story, excuse, etc
invent
children.definition: to think of a story, excuse, name etc that is not true in order to deceive people: bịa đặt
examples: I invented reasons for never seeing him again.
He began inventing excuses for why he had done nothing to help.
He invented fictional ancestors and a family history to impress the girls.
But I didn't invent the story-everything I told you is true.

children.name: make up
children.definition: to think of a story, excuse, explanation etc that is not true, especially in order to deceive people or to protect yourself: bịa đặt
examples: I gave her the wrong name, and made up a telephone number with a Los Angeles area code.
My dad was always really good at making upstories.
I made up anexcuseabout having to look after the kids.
You don’t have to tell him why, just make something up.

children.name: fabricate
children.definition: to think of a false story, piece of information etc in order to deceive people or prevent them from discovering the truth: bịa đặt, làm giả
examples: Officials were accused of fabricating the evidence that was given at the trial.
The woman said she fabricated her testimony because she thought she was going to get a $10,000 reward.
fabrication[C or U noun]
pure fabrication
Police now believe that the whole story was pure fabrication.

children.name: cook up
children.definition: to spend time thinking of a false story, excuse, plant etc, especially with other people: chế
examples: I cooked up an excuse so I could leave early.

children.name: cook up a scheme
examples: He cooked up some crazy scheme for making money, and ended up being arrested.

children.name: concoct
children.definition: to spend time thinking of a false story, excuse, plant etc, especially with other people: chế
examples: His lawyers concocted a theory that the police had planted the evidence against him.

children.name: sth untrue that is said or written
lie
children.definition: something that you say which you know is not true:
examples: Jim said that he was planning to stay home and watch TV, but I knew it was a lie.
a bald-faced/ an outright/ a downright lie[a clear and shocking lie] : một lời nói dối rành rành, trơ trẽn
Davenport said the congressman’s allegations were nothing more than ‘downright lies’.

children.name: lie about
examples: How can the newspapers print all these lies about her?

children.name: a pack of liesso many lies that you feel shocked or angry
examples: He called the report ‘a pack of lies’.

children.name: white lie
children.definition: a lie that does not harm anyone, especially one that is told in order to avoid hurting sb’ feelings: lời nói dối vô hại
examples: It’s just a little white lie. No real harm done.
I told him his suit looked wonderful, which was a white lie.
‘I’m sorry I couldn’t come. I had a really bad headache,’ she explained, resorting to a white lie.

children.name: fib
children.definition: a lie, especially one that is not very important:
examples: You’re not telling me a fib, are you?

children.name: fib about
examples: I had to make up some fib about why I was late.

children.name: falsehood
children.definition: /  an untrue statement or story, especially one that has been carefully and deliberately invented to give people the wrong idea about sb or sth: lời nói dối
examples: Mudge, in a written statement Wednesday, said the article was a collection of ‘falsehoods and misinformation’.

children.name: spread a falsehood
examples: Why Campbell had chosen to spread such a falsehood is a mystery.

children.name: half-truth
children.definition: a statement that is almost a lie because it does not tell the whole truth about sth: sự thật một nửa
examples: McCarthy’s blend of half-truths and lies ruined many careers in government and the professions.
Forbes’ book on Bonham is littered with half-truths, and, in some cases, outright lies.

children.name: misinformation
children.definition: incorrect information, especially information that is deliberately intended to deceive people: thông tin sai lệch
examples: According to Kramer, the Internet is a storehouse of lies and misinformation.

children.name: misinformation about
examples: ‘For months, the Democrats have run television commercials filled with misinformation about the Republican Party,’ said Dawson.

children.name: disinformation
children.definition: false information which is given deliberately in order to hide the truth or confuse people, especially in political situations: thông tin sai lệch
examples: The Russian Foreign Ministry denounced the report as ‘disinformation’.

children.name: disinformation about
examples: Logan said government agents are still spreading disinformation about leaders of the political reform movement.

children.name: propaganda
children.definition: false or partly false information that is spread by a government or political organization, in order to make people support and agree with their political aims and beliefs: tuyên truyền
examples: Propaganda is a tool of war.
Communist/ US etc propaganda
Radio Marti is still there, spewing its US propaganda across the waters toward Cuba.
propaganda campaign[an organized plan to spread propaganda]
In Najaf, Khomeini had begun a propaganda campaign against the Shah.
anti-Western/ anti-Communist/ anti-Labour etc propaganda
a piece of anti-Communist propaganda

children.name: smear campaign
children.definition: when people tell lies about sb in the newspapers, on television etc, in order to make people have a bad opinion of that person: chiến dịch bôi nhọ
examples: Well, Senator Kerry had to respond to these scurrilous attacks on his character as a smear campaign.

children.name: mount a smear campaign against sb
examples: The Labour Party mounted a smear campaign against Livingstone before the election.

children.name: liar
children.definition: kẻ nói dối
examples: She may be stupid, but she’s not a liar.
[ as form of address ]You liar - I never touched it!
call sb a liar
Are you calling me a liar?
compulsive/ habitual/ pathological liar[sb who cannot stop telling lies] tên nói dối quen miệng
Coleman described the president as a ‘pathological liar’ and ‘a criminal in the White House.’

children.name: fibber
children.definition: sb who tells lies, especially ones that are not very important:
examples: You are such a fibber!
Fibber! You couldn't run 10km, let alone a marathon!

children.name: to change facts or information in a dishonest way
twist
children.definition: to dishonestly change the meaning of a piece of information or of sth that sb has said, in order to get some advantage for yourself or to support your own opinion:
examples: The lawyers twisted everything I said to make it look as if I was guilty.
Every time I try to talk to him about it, he just twists everything I say.
Write very clearly so that no one can twist your meaning.
This report shows how she twisted the truth to claim successes where none, in fact, existed.
You're twisting my words - that's not what I said at all.

children.name: rewrite history U
children.definition: rewrite history if a government, film company etc rewrites history, it deceives people by pretending that particular historical events did not really happen or that they happened differently: viết lại lịch sử
examples: Hollywood has been accused of rewriting history, by once again denying the role played by African Americans.

children.name: misrepresent
children.definition: to give people a wrong idea about sb or their opinions, by what you write or say: trình bày sai, xuyên tạc
examples: Your reporter has completely misrepresented my opinions about immigration.
Many women feel that the history books either ignore or misrepresent them.

children.name: distort
children.definition: to explain facts, statements etc in a way that makes them seem different from what they really are:
examples: Newspaper readers are usually given a simplified and often distorted version of events.
These incidents were grossly distorted by police witnesses.
My original statement has been completely distorted by the media.
distort the truth/the facts
Journalists were accused of sensationalizing the story and distorting the facts.
distortion[C or U]
a gross distortionofthe facts

children.name: put words into sb’s mouth
children.definition: to pretend that you think sb has said sth that is not what they actually said or meant: xuyên tạc (suy nghĩ của người khác)
examples: I didn’t mean that at all -- you’re just putting words into my mouth!
You’re putting words into her mouth. You don’t know what she thinks.

children.name: myth
children.definition: a commonly believed but false idea: thần thoại
examples: Statisticsdisprovethe myththatwomen are worse drivers than men.

children.name: hypocrisy
children.definition: when sb pretends to believe sth that they do not really believe or that is the opposite of what they do or say at another time
examples: There's one rule for her and another rule for everyone else and it's sheer hypocrisy.
It would be sheer hypocrisy to pray for success, since I’ve never believed in God.
